pros: Diversity of student body; wonderful campus; great topics to teach. Great professional development opportunities for adjuncts.

review_title: Not a Good Place to Work
pros: Location was good. The students were okay.
cons: Overbearing president, incompetent Provost. Poor facilities.

pros: I enjoyed my time here. I left because of the remote work policy

pros: Students showed incredible aptitude and intelligence. Helpful staff. One of the best HRs in the city

pros:
*Students are driven to succeed
*Dedicated Faculty

cons: I have no cons to share

pros: Some of the folks in other departments, including HR, are great!
cons: Micromanagers. Anti-tech, such that shared drives were forbidden. Demoralizing management styles.

pros: pleasant environment and diverse and inclusive. Good for experience
cons: No work life balance not flexible hours at all. Ver high turnover an no growth of opportunities at all

pros: welcoming environment, very understandable and flexible
cons: hours decreased after pandemic started

review_title: Toxic work environment in chemistry department
pros: The students are incredible and want to learn and be trusted with equipment. Some staff are great, such as the science building's lab manager. The new Payden Academic Center is beautiful and great to work in. The location in DC and from the metro is really convenient.
cons:
This was my first adjunct position, but 6th year teaching chemistry (previously a teaching assistant). First, but this is well-known, the adjunct pay is criminal. A little over $900 a credit hour per semester. 

Due to the high turnover rate, understaffing, and micromanagement, faculty are overworked, tired, and unhappy. My experience working with one such faculty member was toxic, at times contentious, and criticisms of me were not constructive and became personal. Typically a supervisor will be understanding and offer support when someone enters a new job, but I was never sure if I was expected to be independent or if I needed to ask for help. When I wanted to be independent, I was reprimanded; when I needed help or clarification, I was reprimanded. I was constantly dealing with a moving target and could never meet expectations, no matter the effort I put in. Making mistakes was considered unacceptable. My own personal knowledge, teaching philosophies, and experience was questioned. In turn, this caused me to be on eggshells while teaching and being evaluated, thus leading to a vicious cycle. I cut down my hours of teaching because of constant miscommunications, fluctuating expectations, and never be able to be on the same page - in the end, the students ended up suffering from the toxic work environment I endured.

pros: Doing something to help the underserved achieve a college education.
cons: Horrific hellhole for staff. I’ve never been treated so badly in my life. I had to seek therapy after working here.

pros: Important mission in DC and everyone who works there is a true believer in the social justice mission of serving low income students. Students are there to change lives and that was pretty great to be part of. Colleagues are smart and decent human beings. It's a pretty campus with charming old buildings. Salary and benefits are good.
cons: There is an open secret that almost all staff are unhappy there. Worked too hard, without a real voice or opportunity to exercise their capacities. Turnover is routine in almost all offices and that makes the job even harder as people scrambled to figure out how to do the missing person's work. Another issue is lack of autonomy--  I'm pretty sure that no office has a budget and countless, even minor decisions, need to go to the very top. That creates a situation where some people burn out and squelch creativity and initiative. They just do what they can to keep up and find a new job.  The institution doesn't seem interested in getting to the bottom of it. When people leave, they are persona non grata.

pros:
students who want to learn 
small classroom setting
cons: Some of the professor sleep with the students in various departments in order  to ensure their grades.  The president does not support people who are republican and most of the clubs are more towards democratic views. There seems to be issues within the dorms filled with mildew and mold causing students to become sick. There's no way the president is unaware of these issues.  Bullying former alumna seems to be the only strength here. Want to work in a gossip environment then this place is for you. Most of the money is being misused, the school is in desperate need to fix up. Professors are usually talking behind everyone's back and students as well. Most of the time the president is in her office blogging on their laptop and dismissing everything else that is going on. Issues that come to her are usually ignored with something towards the effect of  "I'm out of the office" when she really is there. She seems very interested in keeping illegal students because it helps the school incentives as well as praying on the Black low income students. Horrible place to work.

review_title: Trinity: Doing more harm than good.
pros: Overwhelmingly the students are the best part of Trinity even though a great number of them are underprepared. The parking is free. Its is located in a pretty good part of DC; it doesn't feel much like the city, at all.  The salaries for mid-level employees are comparable to others in the region and benefits are good.
cons: They claim to have a mission of social justice but its really one of social control. The president is overly involved in the day-to-day operations. She sits in her office day in and day out micromanaging faculty and staff when she should be out raising money.  The school is dilapidated, paint chipping, rodent infested--even the students sometimes go without heat & hot water for weeks at a time in the dorms. The Provost is woefully inept and as a result, the place is running on bubble gum and paperclips. And worst of all, she take shortcuts with students.  Too many students graduate unprepared and without completing their course requirements.

pros: Great students. Giving them the opportunity to pursue a higher education and change their lives is very rewarding. Paid time off was good as well.
cons: Extreme turnover. I've seen Deans and Registrar's fired on the spot for disagreeing with the President. It's a heavily micromanaged environment by the President. You will find very few people who last beyond  a year or two. Before taking a job here, mention the name to other colleagues in the field of higher education and they will tell you to run. It's a well known secret to stay away from this place.

pros: Time off is very respectable, and getting a week off is usually easy.
cons: No professional development. Little leadership. Constant problems with Human Resources not communicating throughout the organization. No matter how bad or good an employee you are, you will get the standard raise - not performance-based. Every decision you make will be examined before you are allowed to make it. There is no ability to use existing knowledge - the upper management will do what they feel like doing, regardless of the skillset of subordinate. Professional development is not valued, and rarely approved.

pros:
Ability to take on new responsibility.
Overly qualified employees
Location in the city
There are limited positives to this environment
cons:
Salary
Unclear directives 
Unreasonable goals from management
Overly qualified employees 
No personal development 
No plan to keep staff
Not focused on the goal of educating young people

job_title: Director of Admissions in Washington, DC
pros:
Working to help an awesome group of first generation students
Opportunities to move up 
Great Salary
cons:
Micromanagement
Employee gossip is constant and in every department
Negative work environment - hostile employees and students at times
People in the enrollment office and admissions are expected to work well over 40 hours, many weeks 60+without additional compensation
No bereavement time off

review_title: Students are great, staff, faculty, and good support
pros: Great staff and support for adjunct professors.  The equipment is modern and up to date.  The HR are great people to work for.
cons: Pay is lower then other colleges.  There are older buildings that need to be updated in order to support new talent

pros: I would say that I enjoyed most of my colleagues.
cons: This is a no growth job opportunity for most employees. New ideas are not welcome and technology is a threat.

review_title: Dysfunctional environment, leadership adverse to change
pros: The mission is so important.
cons: Every single department is affected by deep dysfunction. Leadership says they want real change, but stand in your way when you try to create it. No room for career growth. Health insurance is a joke. Serious lack of communication and follow-through. Sadly, the school is not living up to its mission.

pros: Students are inspiring, and most colleagues are congenial. Salary is fair, with good benefits.
cons: There is an air of distrust and over-supervision of workers. Workers feel that they cannot be trusted to do the work they were entrusted to do. Frequently, well-qualified people are treated as if they cannot do a job that they have done for years in previous environments.

review_title: Not a good place to work!
pros: Made lasting friendships with other miserable employees
cons: School needs to do major upgrades to campus, office furniture is used, main areas new students use still look like they are in the 1970's

review_title: Will do and say anything to get you in the door

cons:
